text: morning everyone I'm going to talk to
you guys about how we've implemented
amazon web services at the Centers for
Medicare Medicaid Services we're part of
the Department of Health and Human
Services what drove our cloud migration
was a site called healthcare.gov that I
think people are familiar with we had a
need my team to build three systems on
that website that were designed to
improve the consumer experience to
streamline operations and to scale to
very high volumes those were the
streamlined application the scalable
login system and window shopping excuse
me some of the characteristics of the
systems we had to build or that they
needed to handle extreme traffic spikes
during open enrollment we see very very
high volumes we see volumes drop off the
rest of the year the security posture of
the system it's a very high visibility
website it's a target and so we wanted
to make sure we had a great security
posture the public visibility there's a
lot of attention paid to healthcare.gov
and lastly we needed to rapidly evolved
these systems particularly in the first
and second years of open enrollment we
had a changing environment we had
traffic volumes rising and lowering and
we wanted to make sure that we could
roll system changes out very quickly and
have that agility that we needed in our
Amazon environment we have a couple of
texts acts that we have deployed we have
one Linux tack and so we're using both
nodejs and my sequel and go in Postgres
to run those applications that i
mentioned earlier we do have some
windows environments and we also stood
up direct connect so we can basically
make AWS part of our data center bring
it in and make it a part of our
environment at CMS so how do we do this
and how quickly did we do this we went
from concept to reality we went in about
90 days from the award to being
production ready we leverage the FedRAMP
authority that HHS had put in place and
that's for actually for East and West so
are our use of AWS is in
commercial environments in east and west
and importantly we received we set up an
audit and we received an authority to
operate as what's called the general
support system at GSS and and what that
enabled us to do is to get approval for
AWS the platform so that CMS could bring
other applications into that environment
and we could grow beyond those initial
three that I laid out so what were the
results of our first year first 15
months we did have a successful open
enrollment across those three systems we
offloaded a very very significant amount
of traffic from the other data centers
that are running other parts of
healthcare gov we did maintain the
system uptime goals that we had laid out
for ourselves and we were able to scale
to the volumes we never sort of ran out
of computing power or had to throttle
users because the system was
overburdened and then I'm going to talk
a little bit more later about how we're
evolving our use of AWS to be more
automated we've learned an awful lot in
that first 15 months so I want to talk
about one of the big things that we
learned for us a key lesson was that
when you move into a true sort of cloud
environment and out of a traditional
data center it really flips the model
around so if you look at what we've done
in traditional data centers over the
last couple of years capacity is a
scarce resource there are long lead
times if you want to get new
infrastructure and so what we found
ourselves doing is we sort of starve
development resources it's most
important that production stay up and
stable and the customers can get in and
so there are sort of fewer and fewer
servers in our stack as we move to a
cloud computing environment we found
that the opposite is true that the
resources are limited not by any sort of
lead time to procure them but just by
the budget that we have and so what we
see in AWS is the inverse of this that
we have a lot of development resources
and I think as Mark mentioned earlier we
have room we have capacity to experiment
to try new things and decide if we wanna
roll them out to production as I was
thinking about this diagram backstage I
think the one change that I would make
to this is that the triangle in the
cloud compute is bigger it's a little
bit
this leading here and again because
because of some of the cost efficiencies
we were able to run more compute
resources in AWS than we ever were in
the traditional data center model so
that's an important important value
there and how do we leverage the cloud
in government to me there's a
combination of two things that seem like
they might contradict one another but
they go together very nicely the first
is we've heard of some of the services
that have just been launched and we get
requirements an example that we got just
recently was we needed to basically sort
of have a hot replication between
databases in two different availability
zones in a traditional data center model
we would have either procured some sort
of cots software to do that or we would
have built that since we're in Amazon
they have a service that does that they
have RDS and so we're able to basically
leverage that service and implement that
in a very very cost-effective manner but
the flip side of that is that everything
in amazon has api's and so there are
these pre-built services but what we're
able to do is by leveraging the api's
were able to link those services
together in the way that we need and to
build the programs and tools that
support our production operations so how
do we run at scale in AWS again these
are things that were new to us as we
moved from the traditional data center
model to AWS we are running DevOps and
what DevOps means for us is that the
development and the operation teams are
very very closely linked the operations
teams know what is in development the
development teams know what the
operational model is and so nobody has
surprised as code is getting released we
know what to watch for when a release
goes out we're watching the metrics
we're watching what's happening in
production we are able through the API
as I mentioned before we manage our
infrastructure in version control if
anything ever goes wrong we can go back
and see where we can unit test our
infrastructure which is an amazing
capability we're following the twelve
factor app principles if people aren't
familiar with that again it's a way of
building stateless systems in the cloud
and it's a way of taking advantage of
the capabilities to cloud
for you and we're moving to minimize our
down times by automating the deploys and
we have some systems that might be down
for a few minutes as we do deploys we're
moving some of our systems to sort of
blue-green deploy models and what that
means is there's no down time at all we
spin up a new environment we move the
traffic over we turn off the old
environment nobody ever ever was aware
that we were doing anything in
production and so last i wanted to
mention where we're sort of evolving our
use of AWS the api use i mentioned
before we're building a system sort of
internal to CMS that we call core VPC
that's just sort of our internal code
name for it but on top of Amazon's
infrastructure-as-a-service we're
building a platform as a service that
supports our needs we're leveraging the
AWS api's we have built in all of the
requirements for CMS system so all of
our security or hardening standards are
built in and that's at the VPC on the
ec2 level and so as we bring those
things up they're hardened we know that
we know they're going to work we know
they're tested they're compliant with
all of our rules and I wanted to mention
we I just read an article a couple of
weeks ago from Martin Fowler that was
called monolith first and I really like
the idea which is that you need to
derive a platform from a successful
application and so what we did at CMS is
we looked at our first 12 months of
usage we looked at how we had been
managing the applications and then we
started to build a platform to support
those needs and that will continue to
evolve but it's a way of it's a way of
you know building that platform out so
that it's easier for every single
customer to use as more and more people
come into that environment and again
that's expanding over time it's not a
static thing but it will grow over time
thank you
